messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
I’d be happy to help, but I’ll need a bit more information. Could you share your current latitude and longitude (or a nearby address or landmark)? With that, I can look up which city you’re in.
I don't have that info either.

I’m afraid I can’t pinpoint your city without at least one location clue to work from. Even something small—such as a nearby landmark, a cross-street, your current time zone, or the name of the closest airport—would let me narrow things down for you.  

If you’d like to find your own latitude/longitude to share, here are a couple of quick methods:

• On a smartphone:  
  – Open Google Maps and tap the blue “current-location” dot.  
  – A card should appear showing the coordinates (something like “40.7480, -73.9855”).  

• On a computer:  
  – Go to google.com/maps and right-click (or Ctrl-click) the blue dot or approximate spot.  
  – Choose “What’s here?” and the coordinates pop up at the bottom.

Provide any of those details—coordinates, a recognizable landmark, or even just the nearest city you suspect—and I’ll gladly tell you more.
Could you turn on location services? That might help.

I don’t have the technical ability to activate location services on your phone or computer—that’s something only you (or anyone with physical access to your device) can turn on. Here’s how you can enable it yourself and then grab the coordinates to share with me:

Smartphones

Android  
1. Swipe down twice from the top of the screen to open Quick Settings.  
2. Look for the Location (pin-shaped) icon and tap it so it’s lit/enabled.  
   • If you don’t see it, tap the pencil icon (or “Edit”) to add it, or go to Settings ➜ Location and toggle “Use location” on.  
3. Once Location is on, open Google Maps ➜ tap the blue “current-location” dot ➜ your coordinates appear at the top (e.g., “37.4210, -122.0841”).  

iPhone / iPad  
1. Open Settings ➜ Privacy & Security ➜ Location Services.  
2. Toggle “Location Services” on.  
3. Open Apple Maps (or Google Maps if installed) ➜ tap the blue dot ➜ swipe up on the pop-up card to reveal coordinates.  

Computers

Windows 10/11  
1. Start ➜ Settings ➜ Privacy & security ➜ Location.  
2. Turn on “Location services” and optionally “Let apps access your location.”  
3. Open a browser, go to google.com/maps, click the round “Target” icon (bottom-right). A small box shows approximate coordinates.  

macOS  
1. Apple menu ➜ System Settings (or System Preferences) ➜ Privacy & Security ➜ Location Services.  
2. Toggle it on, then enable it for your browser or Maps.  
3. Open Apple Maps ➜ click the arrow-in-circle icon to center on your location. Press Cmd-I, then Info ➜ Coordinates show up.  

Once you have a pair of numbers that look like “latitude, longitude,” drop them here and I can tell you the city (or the closest populated place). If you run into trouble or prefer to give another hint—like a nearby landmark, cross-street, or even your current time zone—just let me know!
Can you try Google Maps for a hint? If not, that's cool.

I don’t actually have live access to Google Maps or any other external site—I can’t “open” it behind the scenes and pull your location. All I can do is reason over the text information you give me.  

If you’re comfortable sharing something like coordinates, a landmark, a ZIP/postal code, or even a nearby airport code, I can immediately tell you what city that points to. Otherwise, here are a few do-it-yourself ways to grab a quick hint you can copy-paste here:

1. Google Maps (phone or desktop)  
   • Open maps.google.com (or the Maps app).  
   • Tap/click the blue “current-location” dot (or the circle-arrow icon).  
   • A card or pop-up should show something like “40.7480, -73.9855.”  

2. “Where am I?” websites (desktop)  
   • Visit ipinfo.io or whatismyipaddress.com and look for the “City” or “Location” line.  
   • Or try where-am-i.org: it displays latitude/longitude front and center.  

3. Built-in weather or clock apps  
   • Many phones show the current city name on their stock Weather widget.  
   • On a computer, a news/weather tile in the taskbar/dock sometimes lists the city.  

4. Nearby phone numbers or Wi-Fi names  
   • A local business phone number’s area code can narrow things down.  
   • Public Wi-Fi SSIDs (e.g., “LAX-Free-WiFi”) often include an airport code.  

Grab any of those clues—coordinates are easiest—and paste them here. I’ll translate that instantly into the city (and usually the state/province/country as well). If you’d rather not share exact coordinates, even a rounded pair (e.g., 37.4, -122.1) or a recognizable landmark works fine.
